qas.question: Under ancient custom, an Act of Tynwald didn't go into effect until decreed at which location?
Promulgation of an Act of Tynwald originally consisted of reading it in English and which other language?
Nowadays, only the short title and what else are read?
How much of the proposed act must be currently read aloud on St John's Day?

answers.text: only the short title and a summary of the long title

qas.question: On what day does St John's Day occur?
Where is the open-air sitting of Tynwald usually held?
Royal assent gives legal effect to an Act of what?
Since what year has only the short title been read?
The adoption of the Greek calendar was made in what year?

context: Royal assent is not sufficient to give legal effect to an Act of <b6_0>Tynwald<b6_0/>. By ancient custom, an act did not come into force until it had been promulgated at an open-air sitting of Tynwald, usually held on <a0_0><a5_0>Tynwald Hill at St John's<a5_0/><a0_0/> on St John's Day <a4_0>(24 June)<a4_0/>, but, since the adoption of the Gregorian calendar in <b9_0>1753<b9_0/>, on 5 July (or on the following Monday if 5 July is a Saturday or Sunday). Promulgation originally consisted of <b7_0>the reading of the Act<b7_0/> in English and <a1_0>Manx<a1_0/>; but, after 1865 the reading of the title of the act and a summary of each section were sufficient. This was reduced in 1895 to the titles and a memorandum of the object and purport of the act, and, since <b8_0>1988<b8_0/>, <a3_0>only the short title and a <a2_0>summary of the long title<a3_0/><a2_0/> have been read.
